description.narrative:
Front Line Defenders bedriver ett globalt skyddsprogram för människorättsförsvarare. Programmet består av tre huvudkomponenter: (i) akut stöd till MR-försvarare; (ii) förebyggande åtgärder/ kapacitet till MR-försvarare för att öka och förbättra deras säkerhet och medvetenhet att hantera risker; och (iii) externt stöd - förbättrad säkerhet för MR-försvarare genom ökad synlighet och ökad krets aktörer som arbetar för deras räkning.
Front Line Defenders genomför insatsen i nära samarbete med MR-försvarare över världen såväl som i samarbete med ett stort antal relevanta nationella, regionala och internationella aktörer.

The project aims to greater respect for the Universal Declaration on Human Rights and for the UN Declaration on Human Rights Defenders; increased space and capacity for HRDs to carry out their legitimate activities; better implementation of the EU Guidelines on HRDs; stronger international mechanisms for the protection of HRDs.

description.narrative: In 2018, Front Line Defenders (FLD) supported a total of 1,719 human rights defenders and 316 human rights organisations and movements in 93 countries. 86% of these HRDs were able to return to or continue their work following support from FLD's programmes. In 2018, FLDs:• Provided 534 Protection Grants, totalling €1,346,705 to 398 individuals and 136 organisations at risk in 85 countries. This represent an increase of 10% in the number of grants provided from 2017. 183 Protection Grants were provided for temporary relocations. 81% of HRDs reported that they have been able to continue or return to work as a result of having received Protection Grant support. • Issued 186 Urgent Appeals on behalf of 318 individuals at risk in 62 countries. 32% of Urgent Appeal cases resulted in a positive outcome for the HRD at risk. 111 cases were raised by FLD’s Brussels Office with EU Institutions and Member States, while the UN Special Rapporteur on the situation of Human Rights Defenders took up an estimated 85 cases from FLD Urgent Appeals. FLD enhanced the follow-up advocacy on Urgent Appeals, with direct follow-up with repressive governments and local authorities on 41 cases. • Carried out 86 protection coordination, visibility and security advisor field missions to 42 countries. This outreach enabled FLD to expand the network of active HRDs to 10,630 in over 150 countries. • Trained 152 HRDs through 14 trainings on personal and organisational security; 93% of HRDs reported improved security behaviour as result of the training. • Provided personalised one-to-one security support to 150 HRDs through 57 consultations by FLD’s Security Advisor. The Security Advisor continued to target support to HRDs facing urgent risks and in most at-risk contexts, with missions to the Occupied Palestinian Territories, Philippines and Mexico. • Supported 280 HRDs and 180 organisations through an additional 73 field missions by its Digital Protection Consultants (DPCs). In total, FLD’s DPCs delivered 464 individual consultations to HRDs and CSOs. 95% of HRDs reported using digital security tools as a result of the consultancy. • Supported another 174 HRDs through 10 Digital Protection Trainings in eight countries. 66% reported that they were actively using the digital security tools learned on a daily basis. • Supported 36 HRDs through the Rest & Respite Programme. 94% of HRDs reported improved wellbeing following their rest and respite placements. • Led on the delivery of the HRD World Summit in Paris in October 2018, where 150 HRDs attended the event with policy-makers, donors, governmental and intergovernmental organisation representatives, and other key stakeholders; • Raised the profile of defenders through 212 HRD-related stories in international media outlets, and launched the Visibility for Protection workshop programme. • Announced the five winners of its 2018 FLD Award for Human Rights Defenders at Risk: Soni Sori (India), Nurcan Baysal (Turkey and Global winner), the LUCHA movement (Democratic Republic of Congo), La Resistencia Pacífica de la Microregión de Ixquisis (Guatemala), and Hassan Bouras (Algeria). Publicity and visibility events for each winner were held locally or regionally; • Published a series of reports including Stop the Killings, on the killing of HRDs, and Creeping Towards Authoritarianism? an investigation of regressive trends for HRDs in Zambia. Front Line Defenders also completed the final stages of a Gender Audit, with key findings reflected in the new Strategic Plan. A new Deputy Head of Protection was also recruited with specific expertise on gender and with a key objective of developing an organisational Gender Strategy. Front Line Defenders also commissioned an evaluation of the impact of the work in Bangladesh in 2018. In 2018, Front Line Defenders was named as a winner of the prestigious UN Prize in the field of Human Rights. Awarded every 5 years, the UN Prize recognises individuals and organizations who have made outstanding contributions to the promotion and protection of the human rights and fundamental freedoms. Previous winners have included Eleanor Roosevelt, Martin Luther King, Nelson Mandela, Denis Mukwege, Malala Yusafzai, Amnesty International and the International Committee of the Red Cross. For further information and analysis on the developments for HRD's during 2018, please see the narrative Annual Report as well as Front Line Defenders's Global Analysis 2018 (see https://www.frontlinedefenders.org/)
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
